    About me

    Hi folks, welcome to my personal homepage! I‚Äôm a second-year MS (thesis) student in Computer Science at Virginia Tech, advised by Dr. Xuan Wang. I am also affiliated with the Sanghani Center for Artificial Intelligence and Data Analytics.

    My research focuses on making small language models better agents ‚Äì getting compact models to reason well, use tools, and act autonomously without needing massive compute. I work on agentic AI, efficient LLM reasoning, and LLM evaluation. I have published papers at ICLR, EMNLP (Main, √ó2), AAAI (Oral), CVPR, and Q1 journals. I also built effGen (GitHub, 100+ stars), an open-source framework for building agentic pipelines with small language models. Most recently, I spent Summer 2025 at Dell Technologies‚Äô Global Office of the CTO, where I built an agentic system for autonomous resource allocation and received 3 Inspire Recognition Awards for positioning Dell PowerEdge as ‚ÄúAI-native‚Äù infrastructure.

    Prior to Virginia Tech, I completed my Bachelor‚Äôs in Computer Science from Manipal University Jaipur in 2023, supervised by Dr. Nitesh Pradhan and working with Dr. Vijaypal Singh Dhaka and Dr. Mahesh Jangid. I was the President‚Äôs Gold Medalist for Excellence in Research. After that I worked at Dell Technologies for a year as a Machine Learning Engineer, and before that spent 6 months at Swiggy‚Äôs Applied Research (Computer Vision) team.

    Research Interests

    I work on small language models as capable agents ‚Äì the core question being: how far can a small model go if you train and design it carefully? My research touches on NLP, reasoning, model efficiency, and agentic systems. Current focus areas:

    1. Efficient Agentic AI with Small Language Models: I build systems where small LMs can act as autonomous agents ‚Äì calling tools, planning steps, and completing tasks without relying on GPT-5-scale models. I released effGen (GitHub, 100+ stars), a framework for agentic pipelines with small models. The goal is practical: real tasks, low cost, no massive GPU clusters.

    2. Reasoning in Small Language Models and Self-Evolution: I study how much reasoning small models can do and what they lose after compression. This includes chain-of-thought, multi-agent debate, and iterative fine-tuning on model-generated traces so a model can improve itself without human labels (see ThinkSLM and DEBATE, TRAIN, EVOLVE).

    3. LLM Evaluation and Overthinking: Static benchmarks get contaminated fast. I built BeyondBench, which generates fresh math problems algorithmically so evaluation stays clean. I also look at the other side: do models use too many tokens on easy problems? My work on LLM overthinking shows reasoning models can use 18x more tokens while sometimes getting worse answers.
